27 Jun 2016

Guide to Syslog-ng

let's get started !.

    MENU

    • Home
    • Categories
    • About Me

    • Read time: 15 minutes.

    Introduction:

    Syslog-ng is an open source log management tool developed by Balabit IT Security LTD.

    Syslog-ng is developed from Syslog protocol for Unix and Linux systems. in fact Syslog-ng consists of three components:

    • Application for collecting events
    • Data which is logs collected.
    • Protocol for forwarding events.

    There are two editions for Syslog-ng: Open Source Edition (OSE) and Premium Edition. OSE is available for Unix and Linux system. Windows supported in Premium Edition.

    Installation:

    I’m using CentOS , so this tutorial will cover installation in RedHat/Centos ,Ubuntu Distributions using OSE ,Windows users will find Guide for installation here.

    RedHat/CentOS:

    for centOS 6 add this repository and this for centOS 7 to yum.repos.d in /etc/yum.repos.d as follow:

    $ cd /etc/yum.repos.d

    $ sudo vim syslog-ng.repo

    and paste those repositories . then :

    $ sudo yum install syslog-ng

    Ubuntu:

    Syslog-ng has already existed in official Ubuntu Packages ,now type:

    $ sudo apt-get install syslog-ng

    or:

    if you have any error please do the following command instead.

    $ sudo apt-get install syslog-ng syslog-ng-core

    Configurations:

    To configure Syslog-ng ,you should know the basic structure of configuration, you can find Syslog-ng configuration file in /etc/syslog-ng. Syslog-ng configuration is divided into five parts:

    1-source:

    Syslog-ng supported various types of inputs such as Unix-sockets,files,or you can receive logs from a remote server via TCP or UDP.

    syntax:

    source any_name { source_functions();};

    look at these examples:

    source nginx_source {internal(); file (“/var/log/nginx/error.log”);};

    in this example, Syslog-ng takes its input from its logs and from a file called error.log in nginx directory.

    source any_name { tcp (ip(54.23.12.34) port(2000));};

    this one takes inputs from remote server.

    2-filter:

    when you have many traffics from many servers or you search for specific pattern importance of filters is come. Syslog-ng brings many filters that serve our need. syntax:

    filter any_name { filter_functions();};

    these are some of the filter functions you can use: netmask():filters logs based on their IPs.

    filter any_name { netmask(192.54.66.4/24);};

    program(): filters logs based on their programs names in the log message .

    filter any_name { program(program name); };

    message(): filter text of logs based on regular expression .

    filter {message(regular expression);};

    level(): filter logs based on importance level.

    filter any_name {level(priority);}; priority :warn ,crit ,err ,info ,…. or you can select range like: info..warn.

    3-destination:

    after setting your sources and filters ,now it’s time to determine where your logs have to go. syntax:

    destination any_name {destination functions();};

    look at these examples:

    destination nginx_destination {tcp(“43.65.78.3” port(5020));};

    now ,we send logs to the remote server through port 5020.

    4-options:

    Syslog-ng provides good options to control the process of source management such as Syslog-ng can accept or not timestamps from source,destination management such as Syslog-ng can create a directory for logs in remote server , log management such as what is the maximum size of output logs. these are some of the global options:
    log-msg-size(): maximum sent messages in bytes
    log_fifo_size():the number of message that can output queue can store.
    flush_lines():how many lines flushed to destination at time.
    flush_timeout():the time syslog-ng waits in output queue to accumulate the lines which send to destination
    .
    syntax:

    options {options functions();};

    example:

    options { log_fifo_size(800);
    owner(jacky);        #owner of logs files;
    create_dirs(yes);        # create directory in destination.
    group(jacky);        # group of logs files
    dir_group(root);        # logs directory group .
    use_dns(yes);        # use dns resolving or not.
    keep_timestamp(no);        # yes:use default time of logs ,no: use time of logs arriving.};

    5-log:

    now it’s time to flush our logs to its destination form sources controlled by global options. syslog-ng will never know how to work if you not include log section in configuration file. syntax:

    log {source(source section name); filter(filter section name); destination(destination section name);};

    now let’s see this full example:

    options {
    log_fifo_size(800);
    owner(jacky);
    create_dirs(yes);
    group(jacky);
    dir_group(root);
    use_dns(yes);
    keep_timestamp(no);
    };
    source apache_source {tcp(ip(43.42.11.54) port (2050));};
     filter apache_filter { level(warn);};
    destination apache_dst { file(“~/Apache_logs/apache.log”);};
    log { source ( apache_source); filter(apache_filter); destination(apache_dst);};

    in this example, we set global options then set our source to remote server and destination to apache.log file in Apache_logs directory .

    Troubleshooting:

    when you do any work ,you should know how to troubleshoot it .you can make troubleshooting on syslog-ng by :

    • start syslog-ng service in debug mode.

    $ sudo syslog-ng -Fevd

    -F, –foreground Do not go into the background after initialization
    -v, –verbose Be a bit more verbose.
    -d, –debug Enable debug messages.
    -e, –stderr Log messages to stderr.

    • use journalctl -xe :

    $ journalctl -xe

    • use nc -lp (port number) to listen to destination logs.

    $ nc -lp 2000

    • use tcpdump

    $ sudo tcpdump -nS dst 192.168.9.4 port 2000

    now you have a solid foundation on Syslog-ng ,for more information please check resources below .

    Resources:

    Balabit Documentation.
    more about troubleshooting.
    Balabit youtube channel.
